Award.AwardTitle: EAGER. Collaborative Research: Evaluating Identifier Services for the Life Cycle of Biological Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
Unique identifiers are key to current and future access to and use of research data, which are often distributed across a landscape of storage and analysis resources, publishing platforms, and repository services. In the biology domain, researchers and data managers have expressed the need to use identifiers from the moment of data creation and throughout the research lifecycle. A wide range of methods are used in the biological sciences to produce many different kinds of data, which may require the application of different types of identifiers to make connections between physical samples, digital data, analysis, and publications. This project will develop and evaluate proof-of-concept and prototype services with particular focus on DNA/RNA sequence data. This will expand on data modeling work done as part of the iPlant Data Commons, using real world biology datasets from iPlant, the Texas Advanced Computing Center (TACC), and the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON). Project results will be disseminated across the biology and information science communities. Software generated during this project will be maintained in an open source software repository for further development by the community. Some of these products will benefit smaller organizations that provide repository services but have limited software development staffing. This research will inform the development of similar services for different data types and in other domains dealing with issues identification through a project's lifecycle.

There is a growing need for services to verify, track, and report events (i.e. provenance) in relation to identified datasets over time. Such services should start as early as possible in the life of a research project and be as much as possible automated. Much of the current research and development around digital identifiers focuses on facilitating data citation and discovery post-publication. This project will address problems arising for large, dispersed, biology datasets and changing events. Instead of assigning identifiers only at the last stage for curated datasets, usage of different identifiers are assessed throughout the continuum of data management, publication, archiving, and reuse. A prototype identifier infrastructure for identifiers management, permutation, and data validation/authentication across time. The implementation and evaluation of these services will test the use of identifiers beyond the "data publication stage," to connect dispersed data objects as they transition through the continuum of data management, publication, and archiving. This project will develop and evaluate a set of proof of concepts/prototypes to 1) model identifiers to the lifecycle management of bio data including their transition into global, unique and persistent identifiers; 2) conduct automated verification of the data linked to those identifiers to track presence at registered locations and integrity and identity over time; and 3) assess how collection creators use identifiers and respond to identifier services.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Identifier Services  project studied the role of identification in the life cycle of large distributed genomic datasets, in order to streamline their management and publication. When managing genomics data, researchers use many types of identifiers including local identifiers (strings of number and letters made up to identify digital objects), accession identifiers from specimen collections, and globally unique permanent identifiers that are associated with published datasets. In each research project, the use of identifiers is idiosyncratic, and their roles change as the research progresses. Typically, very large datasets are shared by research teams from different institutions, and data is stored, analyzed, and published across different systems. We approached our study of identifiers by building a prototype web portal and web services to test different identification functions through the evolution of datasets as they are gathered, studied, published, and reused.

We designed and implemented different technical solutions around the idea of identity, using our prototype to test them. Users can create custom data models that represent the material entities (e.g., specimens, probes), processes (e.g., sequencing, genome assembly), and data files of their research project. They register data that are distributed across repositories or storage systems - including similar copies of the same data at different locations - and upload metadata (information about the data) in bulk. Once data are registered, users can initiate or schedule tasks to verify their integrity (whether or not the file contents have changed), conduct content comparisons (are two files really the same), and check that data are still at the registered location or locations. We learned that metadata (information about the data) are a major identification mechanism. Identifier Services uses metadata, along with relations among entities in a project, to represent datasets in a graph that reflects the research processes and the structure of the dataset. To manage very large collections, users can create subsets of their dataset that automatically preserve the specified relations among components and relevant metadata. Users can also request global unique identifiers, and use the Identifier Services dashboard as a landing page and track and conduct tasks on their evolving dataset. Our prototype was built over cyberinfrastructure combining cloud, high performance storage and compute resources, databases, and scheduling and data management services, allowing us to address and scope scale and automation.

We began this research with the notion of identifying data (as files or groups of files) using unique strings as permanent identifiers, but progressed towards understanding that identity should be applied to all entities in a project, including material samples, reagents, probes, and processes such as sequencing, alignment, or any kind of analysis. Such identification allows organizing the data according to how research is conceived and conducted by the researchers, which simplifies tracking the many components of large and complex projects. In this project we gained insight into how identity - and the different forms it can take - can help managing data during the research process and beyond, as it is published and reused. Through their two major roles - recordkeeping and publication - identifiers gain and lose functionality. Thus, it is rare that a single type of identifier will serve over the entire lifecycle of a project. Identifier Services allows the use and transition of identifiers as needed.  As we tested our prototypes, we learned the limitations of identifiers and existing technologies. For example, it is difficult to link new derived datasets or correct metadata and have the corrections propagate to related files across different systems, especially when those systems are institutional repositories. The need for mechanisms that can push and pull metadata before, during, and after publication, while controlling for different levels of trust, is a key limitation. Such a mechanism will be a game changer when it is achieved seamlessly.

While both technological and social challenges remain in managing large distributed datasets, the Identifier Services project has shown that solutions are feasible using current resources.The results of this project are applicable to many different sciences beyond genomics, including biomedicine, astronomy, business, and government. Identifier Services can be used independently by researchers to keep track of data, including that deposited in an open repository, or they can be integrated into repositories to tracks datasets as they evolve within and outside repository boundaries.
